Issues.Title: The value of SplitterWidth cannot be set successfully after changing the SplitterConatiner .SplitterWidth
Issues.Body:
.NET Core Version: .NET Core 3.1.101-servicing-014750 from Release branch + the VSIX Inserted into Dev16 16.5.0 Preview 2.0 [29605.132.master]
Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: Yes

**More Info:**
1.	This issue can reproduce with .Net Framework project from .Net4.0 to latest .Net4.8.
2.	This issue cannot reproduce if SplitterConatiner isn’t within panel container.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1.	Launch VS and create a .Net Framework project.
2.	Add a Panel to the form, and drag and drop a SplitterConatiner to Panel.
3.	Set SplitterWidth property of SplitterConatiner in property browser window to 8 (or something other than 4).
4.	In Form1_Load event add this.splitContainer1.SplitterWidth.ToString();
5.	Migrate the code of Framework app to Core app, and run the core app.
[SplitterContainer_SplitterWidth.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/3937691/SplitterContainer_SplitterWidth.zip)

**Actual Result:**
SplitContainer1.SplitterWidth return 4 not 8 after running the app.
![SplitterWidth_Core](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45864017/70403677-89e06580-1a72-11ea-95ad-a7d5218c3860.png)

**Expected Result:**
SplitContainer1.SplitterWidth should return 8 after running the app.
![SplitterWidth_Expected](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45864017/70403682-8cdb5600-1a72-11ea-944f-bf757a672777.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "The value of SplitterWidth cannot be set successfully after changing the SplitterConatiner .SplitterWidth" (#2490)

Issues.Title: Make MenuStrip and ContextMenuStrip look more Windows-native
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 3.0
* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: Yes

With the removal of MainMenu and ContextMenu native wrappers in .NET Core 3.1, and no alternative for native controls, it'd be a good idea to make the replacement strip controls look and feel more native.

Including screenshots from Windows 10 and 7, and `RenderMode` set to `ManagedRenderMode` and `System` to point out differences.

### Windows 10

| Native | Strip (System) | Strip (Managed) |
| --- | --- | --- |
| ![NativeMenu10](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3685160/70310185-5a7dee80-180f-11ea-9ae7-f970c6b69bbe.png) | ![StripSystemMenu10](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3685160/70310193-5eaa0c00-180f-11ea-9f91-48f14507a707.png) | ![StripManagedMenu10](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3685160/70310205-62d62980-180f-11ea-8287-d57b158a70ad.png) |
| ![NativeContext10](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3685160/70308793-57353380-180c-11ea-8005-d8035212a269.png) | ![StripSystemContext10](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3685160/70308811-5f8d6e80-180c-11ea-9296-dc97f56403c3.png) | ![StripManagedContext10](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3685160/70308817-63b98c00-180c-11ea-8bb6-9117a3a5b904.png) |

### Windows 7

| Native | Strip (System) | Strip (Managed) |
| --- | --- | --- |
| ![NativeMenu7](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3685160/70310228-6bc6fb00-180f-11ea-84dc-c3594e5d69e3.png) | ![StripSystemMenu7](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3685160/70310240-6ff31880-180f-11ea-8558-95912eca1c51.png) | ![StripManagedMenu7](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3685160/70310245-73869f80-180f-11ea-9935-ec029d6a8ec0.png) |
| ![NativeContext7](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3685160/70308960-b72bda00-180c-11ea-898f-c5969f4463b4.png) | ![StripSystemContext7](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3685160/70308967-bd21bb00-180c-11ea-81c8-d27a9e2a8951.png) | ![StripManagedContext7](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3685160/70308982-c27f0580-180c-11ea-8f77-21240bad585c.png) |

### Additional Information

The visual differences should be obvious, but there are a few usability differences as well:

* In `RenderMode = System`, the hover highlight over a menu item with subitems - after the subitem menu becomes visible - lingers
* In the native menu, clicking on a menu item when the window is unfocused immediately activates that item; MenuStrip requires a second click
* In the native menu, pressing left arrow key when the first menu item is highlighted brings out the "right-click on window title bar" menu as if it was another menu item: 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3685160/70310763-b432e880-1810-11ea-98f5-f6072ad1f510.png)
* The native menu does not take up any space in `Form.ClientHeight`; when migrating to a `MenuStrip`, you will lose 20 pixels of height
* There is a positioning difference between the native and strip context menu when invoked by a dedicated context menu key instead of a mouse
* Possibly more, this is just what I noticed after a few minutes of testing

### Test Project

The test project targets .NET Core 3.0, and opens 3 windows (native + the 2 strip variations).

[WindowsFormsStripControlsCore.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/3931357/WindowsFormsStripControlsCore.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Make MenuStrip and ContextMenuStrip look more Windows-native" (#2476)

Issues.Title: Windows.Forms.MonthCalendar control throws NullReferenceException
Issues.Body:
Windows.Forms.MonthCalendar controls throws NullReferenceException when the user clicks to change the date

# General

This is a new issue in  .NET Core 3.1. It worked fine in .NET Core 3.0
Operating System is Windows 10 Pro.
This happens if the MinDate and MaxDate are set.

I attached a sample to reproduce the issue.

[WindowsFormsCoreApp1.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/core/files/3927891/WindowsFormsCoreApp1.zip)

I should have posted this to dotnet/winforms. Sorry about that.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Windows.Forms.MonthCalendar control throws NullReferenceException" (#2475)

Issues.Title: Microsoft.VisualBasic.PowerPacks doesn't work with .Net Core 3.1
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 3.1
* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: YeNo

<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/Documentation/issue-guide.md -->

.Net Core 3.1 removed ContextMenu, but the Microsoft.VisualBasic.PowerPacks (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/visual-basic/developing-apps/windows-forms/power-packs-controls)
Making it possible to create but not dispose them.

**Actual behavior:** 
```
System.TypeLoadException: Could not load type 'System.Windows.Forms.ContextMenu' from assembly 'System.Windows.Forms, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b77a5c561934e089'.
   at Microsoft.VisualBasic.PowerPacks.Shape.set_ContextMenu
   at Microsoft.VisualBasic.PowerPacks.Shape.Dispose(Boolean disposing)
```

**Expected behavior:**
Dispose should work

**Minimal repro:**
1. Download and reference Microsoft.VisualBasic.PowerPacks from the line above.
2. Create a LineShape and Dispose it again.

or sample .csproj
```<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk.WindowsDesktop">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <OutputType>WinExe</OutputType>
    <TargetFramework>netcoreapp3.1</TargetFramework>
    <UseWindowsForms>true</UseWindowsForms>
  </PropertyGroup>

  <ItemGroup>
    <Reference Include="Microsoft.VisualBasic.PowerPacks">
      <HintPath>C:\Program Files (x86)\Reference Assemblies\Microsoft\VBPowerPacks\v12.0\Microsoft.VisualBasic.PowerPacks.dll</HintPath>
    </Reference>
  </ItemGroup>

</Project>
```

Program.cs:
```cs
			try
            {
                var sc = new Microsoft.VisualBasic.PowerPacks.ShapeContainer();
                sc.Dispose();
                var sc2 = new Microsoft.VisualBasic.PowerPacks.ShapeContainer();
                sc2.Shapes.Add(new Microsoft.VisualBasic.PowerPacks.LineShape());
                sc2.Dispose();

            }
            catch (Exception ex)
            {
                Console.WriteLine(ex.ToString());
                throw;
            }
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Microsoft.VisualBasic.PowerPacks doesn't work with .Net Core 3.1" (#2464)

Issues.Title: fix: Incorrect invocation of `PeekMessageW`
Issues.Body:
Fixes #2462



## Proposed changes

- During the refactor in d52e526 a number of calls to `PeekMessageW` lost `PM.REMOVE` argument that led to situations where callers would get stuck in a infinite loop peeking for messages.
For example, a form with a `TabControl` with two `TabPage` controls added to it would dead lock and hang.

Fix affected calls by restoring the correct argument.


<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- `TabControl` and other affected controls will work again

## Regression? 

- Yes 


<!-- end TELL-MODE -->



## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->

- manual creation of a test app as described in #2462 and checking that it works as expected

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](http://wpcp.azurewebsites.net/CodeFlowProtocolProxy2.php?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/2463)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix: Incorrect invocation of `PeekMessageW`" (#2463)

Issues.Title: NullReferenceException in ToolStripControlHost
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 3.0.100
* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: Yes

**Problem description:**
NullReferenceException while calling various methods on ToolStripControlHost after disposal.

**Actual behavior:** <!-- callstack for crashes / exceptions -->
`NullReferenceException` thrown
> System.NullReferenceException: Object reference not set to an instance of an object.
>   \+ System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripControlHost.SetVisibleCore(bool)

**Expected behavior:**
`ObjectDisposedException` thrown

**Minimal repro:**
The following code was used in Roslin to reproduce the issue
> #r "System.Windows.Forms"
> using System.Windows.Forms;
> Button btnTest = new Button();
> ToolStripControlHost host = new ToolStripControlHost(btnTest);
> host.Dispose();
> host.Visible = true;

Note: From what I see in the source code, it does not need to be on a visible form to reproduce.

**Suspected Cause**
`Dispose` sets `control` to `null`

**Suggested Solution**
Check for null in the Control property and throw an `ObjectDisposedException` if it is null
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "NullReferenceException in ToolStripControlHost" (#2466)
